More Notes: Claims increase by 0.24% per 1°C increase in daily maximum temperature. This can be considered an avoided impact from adaptation measures.
A day reaching 33–36 °C averages 5.3% more claims than a day 18–21 °C. This can be considered an avoided impact from adaptation measures.

Difference between % increase in claims from pre-2000 and post-2000 for all occupations (0.27%-0.20%). Represents reduced impact, likely driven by compositional change away from high-risk occupations.

Change in % increase in claims from pre-2000 and post-2000 for laborers and tradespersons (0.36%-0.34%). Negligible. It should be noted that the analysis is based on ex-post data and does not involve projected climate or socioeconomic scenarios.
Estimate for production and transport workers
Tradespersons and laborers high-risk occupations, increase in claims due to 1°C increase in maximum temperature
Semi-elasticity of 0.24 indicates that a 1 °C increase in maximum temperature results in 0.24% more claims or an additional 0.5 claims in Victoria per day

The semi-elasticity is a measure of the percentage increase in occupational health claims per 1°C increase in maximum temperature, focusing on different occupations, with separated estimates for all occupations, high-risk occupations, and specific subcategories. High-risk occupations show a 0.35% increase per °C while all occupations show a 0.24% increase.
Labourers and tradespersons make 6.2% additional claims when the maximum temperature is 33–36 °C, compared to 18–21 °C.

Percentage increase in claims per 1°C increase in yesterday's maximum temperature, conditional on today's temperature. Significant at p<0.01, suggesting benefits from reducing past temperature exposure.
Percentage increase in claims per 1°C increase in today's maximum temperature. Combined represents the total effect of a 1°C increase in max temp for a single day.
Cost of additional occupational health claims due to 1.5°C warming, assuming current adaptation measures are maintained, considering all workers.
Cost of additional occupational injuries and diseases due to 1.5°C warming, assuming current adaptation measures are maintained, for all workers.
Cost of additional occupational injuries and diseases due to 1.5°C warming, assuming current adaptation measures are maintained, for laborers and tradespersons.
Average per annum cost of claims due to past warming in Victoria
